title.rendered: New Identity for Givaudan by Interbrand

content.rendered:
Established in 1895, Givaudan is the industry leader in creating flavors for everything from chewing gum to ice cream to soft drinks and fragrances for signature lines of perfume as well as for consumer products like hair, household, and oral care products. Headquartered in Vernier, Switzerland, Givaudan employs over 9,000 people across 88 locations and 34 production sites worldwide. Recently, the company introduced a new identity designed by Interbrand.

Without us knowing it, Givaudan (leader of the flavor and fragrance industry) touches us every day through our favorite perfumes, soaps, and snacks. Ubiquitous but invisible, Givaudan’s presence needed to be recognized and better defined. Since the brand’s competitors tend to focus on innovations in the lab, we felt Givaudan had an opportunity to differentiate by emphasizing emotional connection over technical know-how. Stressing the importance of special scents and tastes in enhancing self-expression and personal experiences, we developed a new proposition that captures the sensuousness and creative spirit behind the Givaudan brand: “Enjoy the essence. Express yourself.” Putting the sensory experience front and center, we conveyed this sentiment across all brand touchpoints.

Interbrand project page

The icon and wormdark remain the same as before but have been separated in order to make the “G” monogram the star of the show by isolating it against fields of black and using it as a window for all kinds of allusive imagery. It’s nothing we haven’t seen before but it certainly transforms Givaudan into much more of a lifestyle brand and name that consumers should be aware of. The images inside the logo aren’t the most imaginative or offer much new in the logo-as-window approach but it’s a tried-and-true approach.

Google-Images-ing “Givaudan” displays a very clinical and corporate aesthetic in its ads and banners. Everything above changes the perception of Givaudan to feel almost like a fashion accessory. So, while nothing visually surprising here, it’s a strong change to make the company more visible and recognizable even when their product is barely tangible.
